column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Do a Messier Marathon
#Text=A Messier Marathon is a stargazing session in which you try to spot all one hundred and ten Messier objects in one night .
#Text=Although it is difficult , it is possible , with some stargazing organisations offering certificates to those who complete the marathon .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Check your latitude .
#Text=The northernmost Messier object is at almost 70 degrees declination , meaning that you have to be north of 20 degrees south latitude .
#Text=The southernmost is at -35 degrees declination , so you have to be south of 55 degrees north latitude .
#Text=The best point is around 25 degrees north latitude .
#Text=Find an appropriate time of year .
#Text=To see all the objects in one night , you have to pick a night around the spring equinox .
#Text=Pick a night where there is a new moon if possible , or a thin crescent if not .
#Text=Search for the times that the Messier objects will appear on that night .
#Text=Create an observation plan .
#Text=Basically , what order you will look at them in , and how long you will spend on each one .
#Text=You 'll want to start with the ones that are only in the sky for a few minutes after the sun has set , and finish with the ones that rise a couple of minutes before the sun .
#Text=Find a dark site .
#Text=You 'll want somewhere away from cities , and you 'll want somewhere elevated , so that objects on the horizon do n't block your view .
#Text=The top of a big hill would be pretty good .
#Text=Get to the dark site and get set up before sunset .
#Text=You 'll be looking for the objects as soon as the sun sets , so you do n't want to be faffing around with your telescope in the dark .
#Text=Get there early , get set up , then relax until sunset .
#Text=Get a computerised telescope ( optional ) .
#Text=That way , you do n't have to swivel it around yourself : just enter the next target and let the telescope do the work .
#Text=Take photos of each object , if desired .
#Text=Use a camera that will time and date each photo , so that you have proof that you did it all in one night .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Do n't panic if you miss one .
#Text=You 'll usually be able to come back to it , and if you miss it , hey , there 's always next year .
#Text=Sometimes there 's two nights in one year , one before the equinox and one after , where you can do a Messier marathon .
#Text=In that case :
#Text=prepare for both nights :
#Text=you can use the first as a practise run , and if it 's cloudy on one night you 'll have a plan for the other .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Do not start stargazing before the sun has set , and stop as soon as it comes up .
#Text=If you do n't , you run the risk of accidentally looking at the sun through your telescope - which will make you go blind .
#Text=Do n't expect too much .
#Text=Astronomical objects always look better in photographs .
#Text=If you 're just using a simple stargazing telescope , you wo n't see very many details beyond a bunch of grey fuzzy patches .
#Text=Not all of the objects in Messier 's catalogue are deep-sky objects .
#Text=M40 is a double star , and M73 is an asterism - a pattern of unrelated stars .
#Text=However , you can still find both of these .
#Text=Watch out for M102 , though - it has n't been unambiguously identified .
#Text=Most people agree that it is either a repeat of M101 , or NGC 5866 .
#Text=Feel free to give M40 , M73 and M102 a miss , especially if you are pushed for time .
